STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 11, 2022
Jennifer Savage
Benzie/Manistee DHHS
1672 US-31 South
Manistee, MI 49660
RE: License #: CP510201273
Benzie/Manistee DHHS
1672 US-31 South
Manistee, MI 49660
Dear Ms. Savage:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on September
27, 2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Implementation, Sustainability, and Exit Plan (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective
action plan is required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also
violations of the MISEP and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days
from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Kari Muntean, Area Manager, at 734-595-0902.
Sincerely,
Doug Turrill, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 11
701 S. Elmwood
Traverse City, MI 49684
(734) 395-0920
enclosure
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of three foster home files contained a special evaluation that documented the
intake occurred on December 20, 2021, and the DHS-259 was sent January 5,
2022, exceeding the 5 working day time requirement for notifying the department.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
is indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
One of three foster home files contained a special evaluation that documented the
intake occurred on December 20, 2021, and the evaluation was initiated on January
4, 2022, exceeding the 7 days as required by the rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance will all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
3

FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans/PATP
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable.
• Caseworker. • Supervisor. • Second line supervisor, when
siblings in care are placed apart. • Parents who are a member of
a participating household. • Youth ages 14 and older. • Foster
parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court ordered
caregiver.
One of three foster care files reviewed contained one or more PATP’s that were
signed late. One file contained a PATP dated May 29, 2022, that was signed by the
youth on August 4, 2022. This same file contained a PATP dated February 28, 2022,
that was signed by the youth on April 4, 2022.
FOM 722-15 Case Closing.
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary,
must be completed at the time of program closure; see FOM
722-08E, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary.
One of two closed foster care files contained a DHS- 69 case closing that was
completed four months after the case was closed. The case was closed on April 11,
2022, and the DHS-69 was completed on August 3, 2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
Technical assistance was provided regarding youth with YAVFC status who are
placed in an independent living placement. Discussion involved YAVFC youth, when
in an independent living arrangement such as a college dorm or an apartment, then
that youth is considered to be in independent living and the independent living rules
apply. The independent living rules do not apply to YAVFC youth living with a
relative, in a foster home, or a CCI.
V. CONSULTATION
Consultation was not offered or requested at this time.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this
licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect during
4

this licensing period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
On September 27, 2021, a corrective action plan was approved in response to those
violations established during the September 1, 2021, renewal inspection. There were
no repeat violations established during the current interim inspection. There were no
complaints filed against the agency during the annual licensing year.
Chief Administrators Annual Assessment: (CAA)
The Chief Administrators report was thorough and well written. The report identified
that staff turnover had created a burden for the agency as the agency was frequently
short staffed during the licensing period. The report also identified that COVID
continued to present obstacles as workers at times were quarantined or children or
families tested positive and were quarantined. Due to the above reasons the agency
did transfer some cases to private agencies however this was limited as the area
private agencies were also experiencing staffing shortages. There were three
unplanned removals during the period, two of which were due to the parent or
relatives’ inability to provide appropriate care for the children. A third unplanned
removal was due to the mental health needs of the youth as she was removed from
residential treatment to a hospital on different occasions.
The assessment also identified areas of deficiency and an internal corrective action
plan was implemented.
Interviews:
A foster care worker and the licensing worker were interviewed. Each staff reported
that they felt strongly supported by their supervisor and that she is knowledgeable
and thorough in helping them complete job responsibilities. Each staff reported that
staff shortages had presented difficulties for the agency and though the team is
small everyone steps in to help each other when the need arises.
Field Analyst Report:
Safety Alerts.
On July 7, 2022, the Field Analyst identified a home which had an outdoor above
ground pool which did not have rescue/safety equipment. The home also had a bed
in the basement which has windows which could not be reached without a ladder in
the case of an emergency, The door leading out of the house to the pool also did not
have an alarm installed. Safety items were ordered through Amazon and arrived July
14, 2022 and were then installed. Pool use and use of the basement bedroom was
suspended until the appropriate safety items were installed. Photos were received of
5

the installed safety equipment and the agency foster care worker verified this in
person on July 25, 2022.
During the entrance conference the Field Analyst provided the agency with
information she had obtained during her visits to the homes. The Field Analyst
reported that foster parents and relatives feel supported by the agency and no
concerns were raised.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of
an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
September 30, 2022
________________________________________
Doug Turrill Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 10, 2022
________________________________________
Kari Muntean Date
Area Manager
